title: Eye Injuries (Children)
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

sections.heading: Call 911 or Go to an Urgent Care Center if the Child Has:
bullets: An object such as a piece of glass or metal or a pencil stuck in an eye (if your ophthalmologist is not in the office)
Uneven pupils (if there's been a closed- head injury )
Problems seeing after an eye injury
Been in contact with chemicals, especially alkali such as drain cleaner

items: An object such as a piece of glass or metal or a pencil stuck in an eye (if your ophthalmologist is not in the office)

sections.heading: Call the Doctor if Your Child:
content: Simply flushing the eye with water often helps when your child has something in their eye. But serious eye injuries need immediate medical care.
bullets: Is younger than age 1
Has been hit in the eye with an object
Has an irritated or red eye
Has continuous tearing
Has an eye that's extremely sensitive to light
Keeps blinking
Has a painful, swollen, or red area close to the eyelid or eye
Has a cut on the eyeball (a cut on the eyelid is less medically urgent)
May need stitches

sections.heading: Treating a Child's Minor Eye Irritation
1. Clean Up
bullets: Wash your hands .

items: Wash your hands .

sections.heading: 2. Stop Rubbing
bullets: Keep the child from rubbing the eye.

items: Keep the child from rubbing the eye.

sections.heading: 3. Rinse the Eye
bullets: Hold the child's head over a sink, facing down and to the side, and hold the eye open.
Gently pour water over the eye for five minutes and see whether the object is out. Repeat up to two more times if the object does not come out of the eye.
If the object is still in the eye, put a light bandage over it (without putting pressure on the eye)and take the child to the emergency room.

sections.heading: Treating an Object Stuck in the Eye
1. Protect the Eye
bullets: Tape a paper cup over the eye.
Do not try to remove the object.

items: Tape a paper cup over the eye.
Do not try to remove the object.

sections.heading: Treating a Minor Cut or Scratch Around the Eye
1. Stop the Bleeding
bullets: Hold gauze on the wound for 10 minutes.

items: Hold gauze on the wound for 10 minutes.

sections.heading: 2. Clean the Injury
bullets: Cover the eye with a cloth for protection, and wash the area with clean water for a few minutes.

items: Cover the eye with a cloth for protection, and wash the area with clean water for a few minutes.

sections.heading: 3. Protect the Wound
bullets: Ask your pediatrician whether you should use antibiotic ointment if the wound is close to the eye or eyelid.
Put a bandage on the wound.
Change the bandage every day.

sections.heading: 4. Provide Pain Relief
bullets: Give child-formula acetaminophen ( Tylenol ) or ibuprofen ( Advil , Motrin ) for pain, if needed.
Do not give aspirin to a child under 16 years of age.

items: Give child-formula acetaminophen ( Tylenol ) or ibuprofen ( Advil , Motrin ) for pain, if needed.

sections.heading: Treating a Black Eye, Bruising, or Swelling
1. Check for Further Injury
bullets: If you suspect broken bones, damage to the eye, or a head injury, take the child to the emergency room.
If the black eye was caused by something hitting the eye, call your pediatrician.

items: If you suspect broken bones, damage to the eye, or a head injury, take the child to the emergency room.
If the black eye was caused by something hitting the eye, call your pediatrician.

sections.heading: 2. Apply Cold
bullets: Put an ice pack on the area for 20 minutes each hour to lessen swelling. Repeat for four hours. Don't press on the eye.

items: Put an ice pack on the area for 20 minutes each hour to lessen swelling. Repeat for four hours. Don't press on the eye.

sections.heading: 3. Apply Heat
bullets: After 2 days, switch to a warm cloth on the area for 10 minutes, three times daily.

items: After 2 days, switch to a warm cloth on the area for 10 minutes, three times daily.

Do not give aspirin to a child who is under age 16.

sections.heading: 3. Immediately Rinse the Eye
bullets: Hold the child's head over a sink, facing down and to the side, and hold the eye open. If outside, use whatever water is closest -- water fountain, garden hose.
Pour water over the eye for 15 to 20 minutes.
If the chemical is in both eyes, rinse them in the shower.
